description.plain:
Mary Jane Blige (b. Jan 11 1971) grew up in the projects of Yonkers, New York. A random decision to record a cover of “Caught Up in the Rapture” by Anita Baker in a pop-up recording booth at a mall led MJB to getting signed by Uptown Entertainment. After providing background vocals on Father MC’s hit single “I’ll Do 4 U” in 1990, a young intern at Uptown named Sean “Puffy” Combs ended up executive producing Mary’s 1992 debut album What’s The 411?. Fusing hip-hop beats with Mary’s soulful voice earned her the nickname “Queen of Hip-Hop Soul”.

She followed up her debut with a string of critically acclaimed albums, including 1994’s My Life and 1997’s Share My World, as well as hit singles such as “Not Gon' Cry,” “Family Affair,” “Be Without You,” and “Just Fine.”

She also collaborated with rappers on a number of tracks, including Jay-Z’s “Can’t Knock the Hustle,” Ghostface Killah’s “All That I Got is You,” Wyclef’s “911,” Common’s “Come Close,” and Method Man’s “I’ll Be There for You/All I Need to Get By,” which was a platinum hit and won the two of them a Grammy Award in 1996 for Best Rap Performance By a Duo or Group.

MJB has become one of this generation’s most successful R&B artists, selling millions of albums worldwide and winning numerous awards. She has amassed an impressive 9 Grammy Awards, including Best R&B Album for The Breakthrough and Best R&B Song for “Be Without You” in 2007. She also branched out into acting, an avenue where she has also won awards for her performance in the 2017 film Mudbound.

songs.full_title: Family Affair by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Family Affair

description.plain:
A song that’s all about leaving your drama outside and getting loose in the club, “Family Affair” was the first single off No More Drama. It remains one of MJB’s most memorable songs and was also her first Billboard Hot 100 single.

Dr. Dre, who produced the track (and who MJB name-drops twice in the song), makes a cameo in the video at 0:20, 2:47 and 3:01.

songs.full_title: Mr. Wrong by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Mr. Wrong

description.plain: Mary J. Blige and Drake take a dualistic approach to the same scenario on this track titled “Mr. Wrong”.  In Drake’s verse, he explains the process of how he may be viewed as being a Mr. Wrong but in a way that it sort of victimizes him.  Mary goes on to explain that even though she knows that this guy is all wrong for her, it feels like she’s making the right decision.

songs.full_title: Real Love by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Real Love

description.plain:
“Real Love” is the second single off What’s The 411? after “You Remind Me” and MJB’s first Top 10 pop song, reaching No. 7 on the Billboard Hot 100.



This song is a perfect example of MJB’s fusion of hip-hop and soul music, something she’s credited with having pioneered.

songs.full_title: Be Without You by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Be Without You

description.plain:
MJB’s 2007 Grammy award-winning single off The Breakthrough for Best R&B Song.

The video, shot in NYC, depicts MJB and her partner arguing to the point where he walks out of their apartment. Alone, Mary begins to miss her partner while reminiscing over some of the good times. But don’t worry, in the end MJB’s partner comes home and the video has a happy ending :)

songs.full_title: Not Gon' Cry by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Not Gon’ Cry

description.plain:
“Not Gon' Cry” went to #2 in the US in early 1996, held from the top spot by Mariah Carey’s “One Sweet Day”. It also reached the top 40 in the UK and New Zealand. “Not Gon' Cry” was nominated for a Grammy but lost to Toni Braxton’s “You’re Making Me High”.

The song was written for the movie Waiting To Exhale, which chronicles the lives of 4 black women. In the film, Bernadine (portrayed by actress Angela Bassett) learns her has husband cheated on her and leaves her after eleven years of being together.

Blige later included it on her 1997 album Share My World.

songs.full_title: My Life by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: My Life

description.plain:
“My Life is the 7th track on Mary J’s second album My Life. This song is one of the greatest songs on the album.

Mary was in London, England when she wrote this song. She also stated that the lyrics took her through a Man in the Mirror quest. Everything she was singing was about her self and was personal things she was doing. The song is  basically a walk in Mary’s shoes, experience things that she has endured.

“I grew up on Roy Ayers. That particular record do something to me it make me think.”

 - Mary J on the Roy Ayers sample selection.

songs.full_title: I'm Goin' Down by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: I’m Goin’ Down

description.plain:
“I’m Goin' Down” was the second single from Mary J. Blige’s career-defining 1994 album My Life and a cover of the classic Rose Royce torch ballad from the soundtrack of the 1976 movie Car Wash.

R&B girl group Y?N-Vee released a music video covering the same Rose Royce song a day before Blige’s impacted radio and TV on January 18, 1995. Blige’s success with the song fully obscured her competitors as Blige’s ascended to #13 on the R&B charts and the group’s stalled out at #57.

Mary J. Blige’s music video for the song was shot in black-and-white and directed by Matthew Rolston. It features the iconic imagery of endless duplicates of Mary in a black pantsuit swaggering rhythmically down a white stairway.

songs.full_title: U + Me (Love Lesson) by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: U + Me (Love Lesson)

description.plain:
Mary J. Blige returns with another heartfelt track detailing the struggles coming off her recent divorce from Kendu Isaacs, which has gotten ugly. “U + Me” serves as a therapeutic anthem to anyone going through a bad break up or tough times with a loved one.

This comes as a follow up to the debut single  “Thick Of It” of her upcoming 14th studio album Strength of a Woman which echoed similar sentiments, so we can expect more of the same going forward in 2017 from the Queen of R&B.

songs.full_title: Thick Of It by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Thick Of It

description.plain:
Even through heartache, the Queen of R&B Mary J. Blige continues to reign. Earlier in 2016, she filed a divorce against her former husband and manager Martin “Kendu” Isaacs. According to the divorce documents, they were both suffering from “irreconcilable differences”.

The separation inspired her hit “Thick Of It” which serves as the lead single off her upcoming  14th studio album Strength of a Woman.

 For the visual of her rebounding heartbreak anthem, Blige rocks in a white, black and gold outfit, while showing off her impressive dance moves in a glistening bronze-like room.



“Thick Of It” went on to become Mary’s fifth No. 1 on the Adult R&B Songs airplay chart, which scored to the No.1 within four weeks. The song broke the record for the fastest climb to No. 1 in over 20 years since Whitney Houston’s 1995 “Exhale (Shoop Shoop)”.

songs.full_title: Just Fine by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Just Fine

description.plain:
“Just Fine” was the first single from Mary J. Blige’s ninth studio album Growing Pains. The high-energy song and its dance-heavy music video were inspired by Michael Jackson’s “Don’t Stop ‘Til You Get Enough.” In sharp contrast to the brooding, brokenhearted ballads Mary is known for, “Just Fine” is unapologetically happy.



Once asked “Do people ever say they liked you better when you were depressed?” and she responded:

I always get that. I haven’t been singing sad music just to sell records. I’ve been trying to talk to somebody to save me. And a lot of my fans saved me. A lot of them helped me. They bought my records and said, ‘You saved my life.’ So, I don’t care what people are saying — 'We’re happier when she’s down.‘ That doesn’t sound right.

Mary’s happy gambit paid off with another hit single that went to #3 on the Billboard R&B charts, and on the Billboard Dance charts, straight to #1 .

songs.full_title: Rainy Dayz by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Ja Rule)
songs.title: Rainy Dayz

description.plain:
“Rainy Dayz” is the 10th track on Mary J. Blige’s album No More Drama.

The song was written by Ja Rule who also features on the track.

In an interview with MTV’s TRL shortly after events of September 11, 2001, Ja Rule talked about the song:

It’s basically about how we feel going through life. But [in] these times, especially right now [with] what’s going on, it kind of fits. On the record, I’m basically saying that it’s these rainy days that we spend a lifetime trying to wash away. Just waiting for the sun to come and shine again. But until then, come smile for me. So that’s the kind of vibe that [the song] is on.

songs.full_title: The One by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: The One

description.plain: “The One” was the brazenly contemporary lead single of Mary J. Blige’s ninth studio album Stronger withEach Tear. The catchy tune produced by Rodney “Darkchild” Jerkins was packed with synths, blips, and autotuned vocal effects that were a far cry from the adult contemporary music that her reserved and classy album cover promised. Nonetheless, the upbeat single with a feature by everyone’s favorite rapper du jour Drake made it a hit with the young, urban 106 & Park crowd.

songs.full_title: Be Happy by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Be Happy

description.plain:
“Be Happy” was released as the lead single to Mary J. Blige’s critically acclaimed sophomore album My Life. Produced by Puff Daddy and Poke from the Trackmasters, the song samples Curtis Mayfield’s “You’re So Good To Me.” The single peaked at #29 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #6 on the Hot R&B Singles chart. The single features a couple of remixes, one featuring Keith Murray and another remix featuring Greg Nice.

In an interview with Bill Bellamy on MTV Jams, Mary talked about the concept of the song:

If you don’t set yourself up to just be happy, period, every day, keep your head up, you’re gonna always be sad. And I had to realize that I have to be happy, you know. So, that song was sort of like a healing process for me. That was something I wrote to heal me.

songs.full_title: No More Drama by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: No More Drama

description.plain:
“No More Drama” was the album’s title track and second single to be released. The video (check it below) features cameos from Mariah Carey & Diddy (at 3:20) and won MJB an MTV video music award for Best R&B Video.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=em328ua_Lo8

This song sampled “Nadia’s Theme” by Henry Mancini – best known for being the piano melody from the The Young & The Restless opening credits (a classic soap opera, filled with drama).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vlv32UEazGc

Note that in the second verse MJB references the sample when she says:

Or maybe I like the stress
Cause I was young and restless

songs.full_title: Doubt by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Doubt

description.plain: Doubt, as the title suggests, deals with issues of confidence. The song plots a journey to success in the face of naysayers that foster doubt in one’s own ability. It is a quintessential anthem that uses the negative comments levelled against the protagonist as positive self-affirmations.

songs.full_title: You Remind Me by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: You Remind Me

description.plain:
The first single to be released off MJB’s debut album, What’s The 411? It reached number one on the Billboard R&B singles chart and was her first Top 40 hit.

In late 1993, on her “What’s The 411? Remix” album, a remixed version of this song appeared featuring Greg Nice – peep the video here.

description.plain: “Glow Up” is a hypermodern trap-influenced sound featuring Missy Elliot, Quavo, and DJ Khaled. Fitting into the post-divorce theme of Mary J. Blige’s album Strength of a Woman, this finds Mary vowing to have fun over a club-ready beat despite being spurned by her lover. She’s gonna “throw it in [his] face.”

songs.full_title: Your Child by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Your Child

description.plain:
“Your Child” was the final single released from MJB’s Mary album. It was nominated in the Best Female R&B/Soul Single category at the 2001 Soul Train Music Awards. A remix was produced featuring Ghostface Killah, reuniting the pair following their 1996 collab on Ghost’s Ironman single All That I Got is You."

Written and produced by Gerald Isaac, this song tells the story about how Mary J Blige’s partner had a baby with another woman while he was in a relationship with Mary and the two women handling the situation maturely.

songs.full_title: Love No Limit by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Love No Limit

description.plain:
Track 7, and the 5th single, on Blige’s What’s the 411?. It peaked at #44 on the Billboard Hot 100 Chart and #5 on the Billboard R&B Singles Chart.

It stands out from the rest of the material on the album with its jazzy sound… but it influenced her music from that point on.

Dave Hall, one of the writers of the song, reflected on the song:

“Love No Limit” was the last record we wrote for the album. I had a deadline to meet and Diddy was pressuring me to get it done,” he laughs. “He kept calling my house and I told him I had this song called; ‘Love No Limit’ that I wrote with Kenny Greene. He said, ‘Cool. Let me hear it.’ So I played it for him and he said, ‘I like it.’ But I don’t think he was 100% sold on it. We moved forward with it even though it was much different from the rest of the material on the album. It was really jazzy. I was big into old school jazz like Sarah Vaughan and Ella Fitzgerald. Kenny Greene was church trained so we did the song with a jazzy feel, but it still had a strong beat to it. He wrote a catchy hook to it and Mary loved it. She definitely loved that type of jazz music. This whole album defined her sound per se. We cut the record and I thought it turned out great, but we were still skeptical on how it would be received because it was so different than any of the other stuff on her album. I was amazed when it came out because there would be guys on the corner in the hood blasting the song.

description.plain:
“Enough Cryin” a song by American recording artist Mary J. Blige from her seventh studio album, The Breakthrough. The song features Blige’s alter ego, Brook Lynn on the sixth verse.

Lyrically, the song is about not emotions over the end of a relationship.

songs.full_title: I Don’t Want to Do Anything by Mary J. Blige (Ft. K-Ci Hailey)
songs.title: I Don’t Want to Do Anything
songs.title_with_featured: I Don’t Want to Do Anything (Ft. K-Ci Hailey)

description.plain:
The 8th track on What’s the 411? is a powerful love ballad sung between then up-and-coming star Mary J Blige and K-Ci from the R&B supergroup Jodeci.

MJC and K-Ci entered into a turbulent relationship that was kept well hidden from the public eye. Suspicions of their relationship began to brew after a heated performance of this song on MTV Unplugged.

Peep this interview where MJB opens up about their relationship and how it served as the inspiration for her second album My Life.

description.plain:
“Be With You” is the 12th track on Mary’s second album My Life. Mary has stated that the song was intended for her cousin.

“I was telling my cousin I don’t understand why every time you know I come around, everybody is angry, nobody wants me around, everybody treats me so bad, everybody is so jealous and mad because you know God is blessing me too”

   - Mary J Blige speaks about the song.

songs.full_title: Love a Woman by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Beyoncé)
songs.title: Love a Woman

description.plain:
“Love A Woman” is the 11th track on Blidge’s 10th studio album My Life II…The Journey Continues (Act I). The song rose as high as number eighty nine on the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs.

In an MTV interview Mary revealed that the song was originally recorded for Beyonce’s 4 album but didn’t make the cut. This is the first duet between the two powerhouse vocalists.

songs.full_title: Work That by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Work That

description.plain:
“Work That” is the second single off of Mary J. Blige’s eighth studio album Growing Pains (2007).

The track was sent to urban radio stations on December 18, 2007. A remix featuring Busta Rhymes was also released to radio.

When it was available as a digital download, the single was still not officially released, but did eventually reach number 65 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number 16 on the US Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs. The song was featured in an iTunes commercial.

In 2019 and 2020, “Work That” received additional exposure after Senator Kamala Harris selected it as the campaign song for her presidential campaign. Harris frequently used it as a walkout song, including her victory speech after being elected vice president in the 2020 United States presidential election.

Following the “Leave a Message” intro, this marks the first actual song on MJB’s debut album. “Reminisce” was also the 3rd single to be released from What’s The 411?, following “You Remind Me” and “Real Love.”

On MJB’s What’s The 411? Remix album, the remixed version of this song featured Pete Rock and C.L. Smooth.

songs.full_title: American Skin (41 Shots) by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Kendrick Lamar)
songs.title: American Skin (41 Shots)

description.plain:
Mary J. Blige and Kendrick Lamar’s version of “American Skin (41 Shots)” uses Bruce Springsteen’s song of the same name as the backbone, while Kendrick adds a new verse. The song, like the original, speaks about the injustice and racism among American law enforcement.

Springsteen’s version was released 15 years prior, but the lyrics are just as relevant to today’s society—if not more. With the recent killing of Terrence Crutcher, among many others, and  police shootings continuing to increase, the song comes at a time of need—another anthem for the African-American population.

songs.full_title: All That I Can Say by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: All That I Can Say

description.plain:
“All That I Can Say” was the lead single from Mary J. Blige’s fourth studio album Mary. The single reached #6 on the Billboard R&B charts and #44 on the Hot 100.

The Lauryn Hill-produced song paints with the same sonic palette as Stevie Wonder’s “Superwoman/Where Were You When I Needed You” while incorporating hip-hop hype vocals and acoustic guitar.

The two collaborated previously when Mary appeared on The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill, as well as an early verse Lauryn had on a remix of “Be With You.”

songs.full_title: Therapy by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Therapy

description.plain:
Theraphy was first single released from the 2014 album The London Sessions. It was co-written with the British singer-songwriter Sam Smith and Eg White and is noticeable for its pared down instrumentation, classic harmonies and minimal beat.

In the documentary film that accompanies the album, British singer-songwriter Emeli Sandé says of Mary J. Blige, “Singing is something she has to do. Because there is no other way. You know? It becomes therapy.”

http://youtu.be/i5NU89g6y0I?start=1m26s&end=1m36s

In interviews Blige has said that she was influenced to make the album by British albums that have come out in recent years such as Amy Winehouse’s Back to Black. Particularly the single Rehab and its honest portrayal of substance abuse. Something Blige herself has battled in the past.

Note also, Sam Smith’s layered humming throughout and towards the end singing background accompaniment. He has often expressed his admiration for Mary J Blige; presumably why he was involved in writing this with her.

http://youtu.be/KUmZp8pR1uc

songs.full_title: Thriving by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Nas)
songs.title: Thriving

description.plain:
In regards to the Mary J Blige collaboration and 2019 Royalty tour, Nas elaborates:

Mary’s been busting it up out here late laying the foundation for hip-hop artist for a long time since her first album. What’s the 411? was like Illmatic to me. It was just a level above – it took over. It was a rap music but singing. It was a blend tape. It changed the game. It kicked the door down and she really walked rappers back into big shows cuz arenas wasn’t getting insured because the great fests and the dope jam tours – people was getting rocked in those arenas so nobody wanted in. They were suing the arenas so it was crazy back then. But Mary was coming out and bringing rappers on the road, bringing rappers to shows where I really looked at Mary as the real Queen of hip-hop before they was calling her that so it’s an honor to be out there with her I’m a big fan of music. I get to hear all of that stuff, it’s like reliving the times of when it first came out What’s the 411? all the way to the My Life album celebrating 25th year. Right now celebrating the 25th year of my first album which I’m tired of kind of celebrating the 25th year cuz we just celebrated the 20th year but I’m grateful at the same time I like beyond what words you know something happy to be there man.

songs.full_title: Love @ 1st Sight by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Method Man)
songs.title: Love @ 1st Sight

description.plain:
Taken from Mary’s sixth studio album, “Love & Life” (2003), the song was released as the album’s lead single in June 2003.



Produced by P. Diddy (that also makes a cameo appearance) and Mario Winans for The Hitman, “Love @ 1st Sight” samples the song “Hot Sex” performed by A Tribe Called Quest.

Can we give these three sincerity?

songs.full_title: It's On by Mary J. Blige (Ft. R. Kelly)
songs.title: It’s On

description.plain:
“It’s On” is a song by Mary J. Blige featuring R. Kelly off of the 1997 album, Share My World.

As of January 2019, the song is no longer available on any re-pressings of the album nor streaming services as Blige removed it, due to the airing of the Lifetime documentary, Surviving R. Kelly, which detailed sexual violence allegations against the track’s featured artist himself. Kelly disagrees with the accusations against him.

songs.full_title: You Bring Me Joy by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: You Bring Me Joy

description.plain: “You Bring Me Joy” was released as the fourth single from Mary J. Blige’s sophomore album My Life. Puff Daddy and Chucky Thompson created the mid-tempo track with a sample of Barry White’s 1977 hit “It’s Ecstasy When You Lay Down Next to Me.” In 1995, the single peaked at #57 on the Billboard Hot 100, #29 on the Hot R&B Singles chart, and topped the Hot Dance Club Songs chart.

songs.full_title: Deep Inside by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Elton John)
songs.title: Deep Inside

description.plain:
Deep Inside is the second single from Mary J. Blige’s fourth album, “Mary”.

It notably features replayed piano portions of Elton John’s “Bennie and the Jets”.

Rather than use a direct sample of “Bennie and the Jets”, The replayed elements of were played by Elton John himself.

https://youtu.be/hYtJM7x8epQ?t=249

songs.full_title: PMS by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: PMS

description.plain:
MJB shares something for the ladies to relate to – a song about PMS aka premenstrual syndrome.

MJB actually got into a brief discussion about PMS during a 2006 interview with Oprah:


Mary: I have PMS days when I go back to excessive spending. I still have a lot of work to do on myself. Change doesn’t happen overnight.
[…]
Oprah: Earlier, you mentioned PMS. Does it hit you hard?

M: God, yes! I need some kind of drug for it. My past always seems to come up during that time. Sugar makes it worse.

O: Chocolate makes it worse.

M: I’d always thought chocolate soothed PMS. It doesn’t. Just ask my husband.

songs.full_title: Rise Up Shepherd and Follow by Mary J. Blige (Ft. Nas)
songs.title: Rise Up Shepherd and Follow
songs.title_with_featured: Rise Up Shepherd and Follow (Ft. Nas)

description.plain:
This is more than a Christmas song, it’s deeper than that. It’s kind of like you’re the shepherd, God is the Northern Star and the right lifestyle is Jesus.

It’s telling you to change your old ways (rise up shepherd) and follow God’s (and follow). When Nas says “Christ is born” he means a new you/lifestyle, that you’re no longer the shepherd, you are Christ, and you’re going to be a “ghetto prophet” and show “[your] people” the new way and be their Messiah.

songs.full_title: Leave a Message by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Leave a Message

description.plain:
The opening track for the Queen of Hip Hop Soul’s debut album, What’s the 411?.

The album’s intro consists of a skit with executive producer for the album Puff Daddy failing to get ahold of MJB on her phone. We then hear phone messages from several of MJB’s other colleagues, each giving her praise surrounding the album.

Given that the album’s title was derived from MJB’s past job as a 411 telephone operator, this intro seems particularly well suited.

The drum beat looping throughout the track is sampled from “PSK, What Does It Mean?” by Schoolly D:

http://youtu.be/fQc4A-XBzBY?t=13s

description.plain: In this song Mary is reflecting on how much she likes this new guy she’s seeing but struggles with letting him in. She can’t help but hesitate about being open with because she’s been hurt before and doesn’t want that to happen again.

The eleventh track on Mary J. Blige’s album The London Sessions is another collaboration with Disclosure.

songs.full_title: My Life '06 by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: My Life ’06

description.plain:
Mary J. Blige re-recorded “My Life,” the title cut from her 1994 sophomore album, for inclusion on her greatest hits album Reflections (A Retrospective). Showing off her more controlled voice and mature outlook, she recreates “My Life” nearly lick-for-lick, but this time over a brand new track produced by then-husband Kendu Isaacs.

The new track, while borrowing elements from Chucky Thompson’s original production, is now supported by live drums, guitars, and a smartly arranged horn section giving the new version of the song the feel of a special event live performance. The iconic sample of Roy Ayers' “Everybody Loves The Sunshine” remains intact.

She also gives commentary on her process of maturation in the 12 years since the song’s original release by adding an additional verse to the song. The jazzy arrangement caps off with Blige scatting her way through the track.

songs.full_title: Kitchen by Mary J. Blige
songs.title: Kitchen

description.plain:
“Kitchen” is the eleventh track of Mary J. Blige’s ninth studio album STRONGER withEach Tear (2009).

In this Prince-influenced track Mary uses humorous cooking and food metaphors to advise women to keep female vixens away from their men, who are seen more as investments of time and energy than romantic paragons.

“Kitchen” ends up becoming an amusing song about how allowing your female friends too close to your dude is a major no-no if you don’t want static. You know how these single women can get sometimes :)!
